articles.headline: U.N. to Investigate Claim That Employees Participated in Oct. 7 Attack
articles.snippet: The United States temporarily cut off funding to UNRWA, the agency that aids Palestinians, citing allegations that 12 of its workers were involved in the Hamas-led assault on southern Israel.
articles.abstract: The United States temporarily cut off funding to UNRWA, the agency that aids Palestinians, citing allegations that 12 of its workers were involved in the Hamas-led assault on southern Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Nations on Friday fired 12 of its employees in Gaza and began an investigation into them after accusations by Israel that they had helped plan and had participated in the Oct. 7 terrorist assault that left about 1,200 Israelis dead and more than 240 others captured.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi, Edward Wong, Russell Goldman and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: Buried in Wegovy Costs, North Carolina Will Stop Paying for Obesity Drugs
articles.snippet: Starting April 1, state employees in North Carolina will no longer have insurance coverage for costly weight-loss medications like Wegovy and Zepbound.
articles.abstract: Starting April 1, state employees in North Carolina will no longer have insurance coverage for costly weight-loss medications like Wegovy and Zepbound.
articles.lead_paragraph: In June 2021, the insurance plan for North Carolina state employees was paying for 2,800 people to take weight-loss drugs.

articles.headline: Why Nikki Haley Has So Few Friends Left in South Carolina Politics
articles.snippet: Nikki Haley could use some help rescuing her campaign. But Republicans in her home state are flocking to Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: Nikki Haley could use some help rescuing her campaign. But Republicans in her home state are flocking to Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stories pile up one after another, of thanks not offered, allies antagonized, opponents not forgiven — a portrait of a politician who climbed the ladder with speed and skill but failed to ensure that the people who helped her would have her back if she needed them.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: U.N. Court Orders Israel to Prevent Genocide, but Does Not Demand Stop to War
articles.snippet: The top United Nations court in The Hague did not rule on whether Israel was committing genocide in Gaza, the accusation that South Africa brought before the court.
articles.abstract: The top United Nations court in The Hague did not rule on whether Israel was committing genocide in Gaza, the accusation that South Africa brought before the court.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Nations’ highest court said on Friday that Israel must take action to prevent acts of genocide by its forces in the Gaza Strip, adding to the international pressure on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to reduce death and destruction in the battered Palestinian enclave.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Raja Abdulrahim, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: FIFA Convictions Are Imperiled by Questions of U.S. Overreach
articles.snippet: Two Supreme Court decisions and a lower court’s ruling have cast doubt on the legal basis for a host of prosecutions. Several defendants want their records cleared and their money back.
articles.abstract: Two Supreme Court decisions and a lower court’s ruling have cast doubt on the legal basis for a host of prosecutions. Several defendants want their records cleared and their money back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly a decade after police officers marched world soccer officials out of a luxury hotel in Zurich at dawn, revealing a corruption scandal that shook the world’s most popular sport, the case is at risk of falling apart.
articles.byline: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Tariq Panja

articles.headline: A Collective ‘No’: Anti-Putin Russians Embrace an Unlikely Challenger
articles.snippet: Long lines have popped up in Russia and beyond to get Boris B. Nadezhdin, an antiwar candidate, onto the ballot for Russia’s presidential election in March.
articles.abstract: Long lines have popped up in Russia and beyond to get Boris B. Nadezhdin, an antiwar candidate, onto the ballot for Russia’s presidential election in March.
articles.lead_paragraph: His surname comes from the Russian word for hope — and for hundreds of thousands of antiwar Russians, that is, improbably enough, what he has become.
articles.byline: By Paul Sonne, Alina Lobzina and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: Private Equity Is Starting to Share With Workers, Without Taking a Financial Hit
articles.snippet: The buyout giant KKR pioneered a model of granting ownership stakes to employees at portfolio companies. Now it wants the approach to spread.
articles.abstract: The buyout giant KKR pioneered a model of granting ownership stakes to employees at portfolio companies. Now it wants the approach to spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2018, Anna-Lisa Miller was working with agricultural cooperatives in Hawaii, helping them reinvest in their communities through shared ownership.

articles.headline: Where Is Hamas Getting Its Weapons? Increasingly, From Israel.
articles.snippet: The very weapons that Israeli forces have used to enforce a blockade of Gaza are now being used against them.
articles.abstract: The very weapons that Israeli forces have used to enforce a blockade of Gaza are now being used against them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli military and intelligence officials have concluded that a significant number of weapons used by Hamas in the Oct. 7 attacks and in the war in Gaza came from an unlikely source: the Israeli military itself.
articles.byline: By Maria Abi-Habib and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: Black Pastors Pressure Biden to Call for a Cease-Fire in Gaza
articles.snippet: Black congregants’ dismay at President Biden’s posture on the war could imperil his re-election bid.
articles.abstract: Black congregants’ dismay at President Biden’s posture on the war could imperil his re-election bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Israel-Hamas war enters its fourth month, a coalition of Black faith leaders is pressuring the Biden administration to push for a cease-fire — a campaign spurred in part by their parishioners, who are increasingly distressed by the suffering of Palestinians and critical of the president’s response to it.

articles.headline: Trump and Biden Get Ready for the Very Long Haul
articles.snippet: The 2024 general election campaign is set to be one of the longest in modern history. There will be no spring break.
articles.abstract: The 2024 general election campaign is set to be one of the longest in modern history. There will be no spring break.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Donald J. Trump rapidly closing in on the Republican presidential nomination, the 2024 general election campaign is set to be one of the longest in modern history, pushing President Biden and Mr. Trump into unfamiliar territory as they struggle to engage an electorate that seems numbed by the prospect of a 2020 rematch.

articles.headline: Since Ohio Train Derailment, Accidents Have Gone Up, Not Down
articles.snippet: The total number of accidents for the top five freight railroads increased, and Congress still hasn’t passed legislation to prevent similar disasters.
articles.abstract: The total number of accidents for the top five freight railroads increased, and Congress still hasn’t passed legislation to prevent similar disasters.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a freight train carrying hazardous chemicals derailed a year ago in East Palestine, Ohio, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of residents and upending life in the town for months, the rail industry pledged to work to become safer, and members of Congress vowed to pass legislation to prevent similar disasters.

articles.headline: 3 American Soldiers Killed in Drone Strike in Jordan, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: The White House blamed an Iranian-backed militia for the attack. The deaths were the first known fatalities of U.S. forces from hostile fire in the turmoil spreading in the Middle East.
articles.abstract: The White House blamed an Iranian-backed militia for the attack. The deaths were the first known fatalities of U.S. forces from hostile fire in the turmoil spreading in the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three U.S. service members were killed in Jordan on Sunday and at least 34 others were injured in what the Biden administration said was a drone attack from an Iran-backed militia, the first known American military fatalities from hostile fire in the turmoil spilling over from Israel’s war with Hamas.

articles.headline: At the Defense Table, Trump Uses the Courtroom as a Stage
articles.snippet: In two civil trials, the former president has showcased his disdain for the legal system and provided a preview of how he might handle himself when any of his four criminal cases go to trial.
articles.abstract: In two civil trials, the former president has showcased his disdain for the legal system and provided a preview of how he might handle himself when any of his four criminal cases go to trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: He shook his head in anger, sitting with his back hunched. He spoke to his lawyers, his words sometimes quite audible to the packed courtroom. He wrote instructions for his defense team that he shoved their way. He walked in late at one point, and at another, while a lawyer suing him was speaking to the jury, he stalked out.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Kate Christobek

articles.headline: Sexual Assault Claims Against McMahon Shadow a W.W.E. Trying to Move Forward
articles.snippet: Several high-profile deals have the company well-positioned for years to come, but legal entanglements involving Vince McMahon, its former, longtime leader, are not going away.
articles.abstract: Several high-profile deals have the company well-positioned for years to come, but legal entanglements involving Vince McMahon, its former, longtime leader, are not going away.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cody Rhodes emerged victorious from World Wrestling Entertainment’s “Royal Rumble” on Saturday night, an annual marquee event for the company that culminates in a battle royale match in which 30 wrestlers enter the ring and fight it out until only one remains.

articles.headline: Details Emerge on U.N. Workers Accused of Aiding Hamas Raid
articles.snippet: Israeli officials have presented evidence they say ties workers at a Palestinian aid agency in Gaza to violence during the Hamas-led attack on Israel.
articles.abstract: Israeli officials have presented evidence they say ties workers at a Palestinian aid agency in Gaza to violence during the Hamas-led attack on Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: One is accused of kidnapping a woman. Another is said to have handed out ammunition. A third was described as taking part in the massacre at a kibbutz where 97 people died. And all were said to be employees of the United Nations aid agency that schools, shelters and feeds hundreds of thousands of Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: Evergrande Will Be Dismantled, a ‘Big Bang’ End to Years of Stumbles
articles.snippet: After multiple delays and even a few faint glimmers of hope, a Hong Kong court has sounded the death knell for what was once China’s biggest real estate firm.
articles.abstract: After multiple delays and even a few faint glimmers of hope, a Hong Kong court has sounded the death knell for what was once China’s biggest real estate firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Months after China Evergrande ran out of cash and defaulted in 2021, investors around the world scooped up the property developer’s discounted i.o.u.’s, betting that the Chinese government would eventually step in to bail it out.

articles.headline: Inside Biden’s Anti-Trump Battle Plan (and Where Taylor Swift Fits In)
articles.snippet: Watching Donald Trump ascend, the newly energized Biden campaign is aiming to make the general election all about him. It’s also hoping for some big endorsements.
articles.abstract: Watching Donald Trump ascend, the newly energized Biden campaign is aiming to make the general election all about him. It’s also hoping for some big endorsements.
articles.lead_paragraph: As former President Donald J. Trump speeds toward the Republican nomination, President Biden is moving quickly to pump energy into his re-election bid, kicking off what is likely to be an ugly, dispiriting and historically long slog to November between two unpopular nominees.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein, Lisa Lerer, Katie Glueck and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: An Italian Holocaust Survivor Asks if She Has ‘Lived in Vain’
articles.snippet: Liliana Segre, who has become Italy’s conscience on the Holocaust, says she is pessimistic in the face of rising anti-Semitism.
articles.abstract: Liliana Segre, who has become Italy’s conscience on the Holocaust, says she is pessimistic in the face of rising anti-Semitism.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Liliana Segre visited Italian classrooms to recount her expulsion from school under Benito Mussolini’s anti-Semitic racial laws, her doomed attempt to flee Nazi-controlled Italy, her deportation from Milan’s train station to the death camps of Auschwitz. Her plain-spoken testimony about gas chambers, tattooed arms, casual atrocities and the murders of her father, grandparents and thousands of other Italian Jews made her the conscience and living memory of a country that often prefers not to remember.

articles.headline: Voting Is Bewildering This Primary Season. That Worries Experts.
articles.snippet: New Hampshire’s ballot didn’t include President Biden. South Carolina has two primaries. Nevada has a primary and a caucus. A morass of dates and formats could keep some voters away.
articles.abstract: New Hampshire’s ballot didn’t include President Biden. South Carolina has two primaries. Nevada has a primary and a caucus. A morass of dates and formats could keep some voters away.
articles.lead_paragraph: Democracy is messy, but usually not this messy.
